channel.title: Kevin Froman's blog
channel.description: Kevin Froman's blog on security, programming, and other musings

item.title: bitcoin shoplifting: hacking openbazaar 1.0
item.description: As part of my research into P2P software, I decided to give OpenBazaar (1.0) a quick look over to see if I could catch any security issues. (This was not an audit, just a short examination).

item.title: tls key reuse on popular router models
item.description: Recently I have been researching security of consumer Internet and WiFi routers.

item.title: hijacking gandi.net domains and servers
item.description: [Gandi.net](https://www.gandi.net/), a popular domain registrar and hosting provider used by somewhat high profile organizations, such as the [EFF](https://eff.org) and [Free Software Foundation](https://fsf.org/), had an XSS vulnerability on its main domain name (www.gandi.net).

item.title: zeronet: death by svg
item.description: An often overlooked feature of [SVGs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Svg) is their ability to have embedded scripts, like HTML pages.

item.title: creating minecraft plugins in any programming language
item.description: This is a bit of a different post from what I usually write about, but hopefully those who are interested in programming, Linux, or Minecraft will enjoy it.

item.title: using caddy to create a secure socket server
timebleed breaking privacy with a simple timing attack
tracking ipfs users via cache probing
how a random github repo led to a shell access google dork
item.description: Developers often publicly release code that is barely tested, or meant for personal reasons, such as quick scripts or weekend experiments.

item.title: Exploiting I2P 3
item.description: *This is part 3 in my series of exploits in I2P/related software, I recommend reading the [1st](/blog/stealing-your-I2P-email.html) and [2nd](/blog/exploiting-I2P-Bote.html) posts first*.

item.title: do not trust x forwarded for
how i could have compromised MIT app inventor
